org.mt4j.input.inputProcessors.componentProcessors.tapAndHoldProcessor
Class TapAndHoldProcessor

java.lang.Object
  org.mt4j.input.inputProcessors.componentProcessors.AbstractComponentProcessor
      org.mt4j.input.inputProcessors.componentProcessors.AbstractCursorProcessor
          org.mt4j.input.inputProcessors.componentProcessors.tapAndHoldProcessor.TapAndHoldProcessor
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Comparable<AbstractComponentProcessor>, IMTInputEventListener, IInputProcessor, IPreDrawAction
public class TapAndHoldProcessor
extends AbstractCursorProcessor
implements IPreDrawAction

The Class TapAndHoldProcessor. Multi-Touch gesture which is triggered after touching and resting the finger on the same spot for some time. Only works with the first cursor entering the component. Cancels if the finger is moved beyond a specified threshold distance. Fires TapAndHoldEvent gesture events.

Author:
Christopher Ruff

cursorLocked

public void cursorLocked(InputCursor c,
                         IInputProcessor lockingAnalyzer)
Description copied from class: AbstractCursorProcessor
This method is called if a input processor with a higher locking-priority than this one successfully locked the specified cursor which was previously locked by this processor. We should stop using it and end the gesture until it is unlocked by the other processor again! So when this method is invoked, usually we can follow these instructions in our processor:
-> if we can't continue the gesture without the cursor that we just lost the lock on (usually the case)
-> unlock all other cursors that we used in this processor/gesture ( unlockAllCursors())
-> fire a gesture event with ID = GESTURE_ENDED

Specified by:
cursorLocked in class AbstractCursorProcessor
Parameters:
c - the cursor
lockingAnalyzer - the locking processor

cursorUnlocked

public void cursorUnlocked(InputCursor c)
Description copied from class: AbstractCursorProcessor
This method is called if an input processor with a higher locking-priority than this one releases his lock on the specified cursor (i.e. because the conditions for continuing the gesture aren't met anymore). This gives this input processor the chance to see if it can use the cursor and try to lock it again.
So first of all we should check if our gesture in this processor is still in progress and if it isnt we can check if the cursor is still free for us to lock. using canLock(cursor) and then obtain the lock using getLock(cursor); So when this method is invoked, usually we can follow these instructions in our processor:
-> Is the processor/gesture resumable?
-> If not -> do nothing, we don't want any released cursor that was used by a higher priority gesture previously
-> If yes -> check if the gesture is still in progress (i.e. by checking if the getLockedCursors() list has the same size as the cursors used by this processor/gesture
-> Check if all gesture preconditions are met and we can lock the cursor(s) using canLock(..) to restart the gesture
-> lock the cursor(s) using getLock(..)
-> fire a new gesture event with id = GESTURE_

Specified by:
cursorUnlocked in class AbstractCursorProcessor
Parameters:
c - the cursor

setMaxFingerUpDist

public void setMaxFingerUpDist(float maxFingerUpDist)
Sets the maximum allowed distance of the position of the finger_down event and the finger_up event that fires a click event
This ensures that a click event is only raised if the finger didnt move that far during the click.

Parameters:
maxFingerUpDist - the max finger up dist
